greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Bigomega of the n-th Catalan number: a(n) = A001222(A000108(n)).
comment: It is easy to show that a(n) is between n/log(n) and 2n/log(n) (for n>n0), cf. [Campbell 1984]. The sequence A137687, roughly the middle of this interval, is a fair approximation for A081399. See A137686 for the (signed) difference of the two sequences.
link: M. F. Hasler, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..3000.
Douglas M. Campbell, The Computation of Catalan Numbers, Mathematics Magazine, Vol. 57, No. 4. (Sep., 1984), pp. 195-208.
maple: with(numtheory):a:=proc(n) if n=0 then 0 else bigomega(binomial(2*n,n)/(1+n)) fi end: seq(a(n), n=0..75); # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Apr 11 2008
mathematica: a[n_] := PrimeOmega[ CatalanNumber[n]]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 75}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 02 2013 *)
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Mar 28 2003
ext: Edited and extended by _M. F. Hasler_, Feb 06 2008
